title: Josip Filipović
text:
Josip Filipović, "<a href="Freiherr">Freiherr</a>" (Baron) von Philippsberg, also Josef von Philippovich or Joseph Philippovich (April 1818 – 6 August 1889), was an <a href="Austro-Hungarian">Austro-Hungarian</a> general ("<a href="Feldzeugmeister">Feldzeugmeister</a>").
Life and career.
Filipović was born in the <a href="Military%20Frontier">Military Frontier</a> town of <a href="Gospi%C4%87">Gospić</a>, then in <a href="Austrian%20Empire">Austrian Empire</a>. He joined the <a href="Austro-Hungarian%20Army">Austrian Army</a> in 1836 and became <a href="major">major</a> in 1848. He fought under <a href="Josip%20Jela%C4%8Di%C4%87">Josip Jelačić</a> in <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Hungary%20%281526%E2%80%931867%29">Hungary</a>, helping to quell the <a href="The%20Revolutions%20of%201848%20in%20the%20Habsburg%20areas">1848 Revolutions</a>. 
He became <a href="colonel">colonel</a> and commander of the 5th border regiment in 1857, and scored victories at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Solferino">Battle of Solferino</a> in 1859 and in the <a href="Austro-Prussian%20War">Austro-Prussian War</a> in 1866. At one point He was commander of a <a href="Vienna">Viennese</a> division and for a short time was promoted from general to <a href="colonel%20general">colonel general</a>. 
In 1859 he became <a href="major%20general">major general</a> and fought with the 6th corps in Italy, for which he was rewarded with the hereditary title of "Freiherr". In 1866 he fought in <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Bohemia">Bohemia</a> campaign with the 2nd corps.
Filipović moved further up through the ranks, stationed in <a href="Vienna">Vienna</a>, <a href="German%20Tyrol">Tyrol</a>, <a href="Vorarlberg">Vorarlberg</a> and <a href="Brno">Brno</a>, where he was made <a href="Feldzeugmeister">Feldzeugmeister</a> in January 1874. In June 1874, he became the commander of the army in Bohemia, a position he would hold until his death.
In July 1878 he commanded the troops <a href="Austro-Hungarian%20occupation%20of%20Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina">invading Bosnia and Herzegovina</a>. After three months of battle his troops captured <a href="Sarajevo">Sarajevo</a> on 19 August, which then became the capital. The occupation of Herzegovina was assigned to his subordinate Feldmarschalleutnant <a href="Stjepan%20Jovanovi%C4%87">Stjepan Jovanović</a>. He returned to Vienna in 1880 and to Prague in 1882.
Filipović died in <a href="Prague">Prague</a> (at the time <a href="Austria-Hungary">Austro-Hungarian Empire</a>, now <a href="Czech%20Republic">Czech Republic</a>). For his merits he was awarded the Commander's Cross of the <a href="Order%20of%20Maria%20Theresa">Order of Maria Theresa</a> in 1879.
